# Cambridge International AS & A Level  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 171, 196, 202]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 221, 171, 250]]<|/det|>

CANDIDATE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[737, 214, 907, 255]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 277, 232, 293]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[836, 277, 907, 293]]<|/det|>
9709/62  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 303, 343, 319]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Probability & Statistics 2  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[730, 303, 907, 320]]<|/det|>
February/March 2020  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 329, 907, 345]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 357, 395, 373]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 384, 390, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 418, 225, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 435, 875, 632]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 664, 217, 679]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 680, 732, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
The booklets produced by a certain publisher contain, on average, 1 incorrect letter per 30 000 letters, and these errors occur randomly. A randomly chosen booklet from this publisher contains 12 500 letters.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
Use a suitable approximating distribution to find the probability that this booklet contains at least 2 errors. [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
Lengths of a certain species of lizard are known to be normally distributed with standard deviation \(3.2 \text{cm}\). A naturalist measures the lengths of a random sample of 100 lizards of this species and obtains an \(\alpha \%\) confidence interval for the population mean. He finds that the total width of this interval is \(1.25 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 151, 180, 168]]<|/det|>
Find \(\alpha\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 151, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
In the past, the mean time taken by Freda for a particular daily journey was 39.2 minutes. Following the introduction of a one-way system, Freda wishes to test whether the mean time for the journey has decreased. She notes the times, \(t\) minutes, for 40 randomly chosen journeys and summarises the results as follows.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[339, 139, 658, 158]]<|/det|>
\[n = 40\qquad \Sigma t = 1504\qquad \Sigma t^2 = 57 760\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 175, 146, 193]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 173, 920, 193]]<|/det|>
Calculate unbiased estimates of the population mean and variance of the new journey time. [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 381, 148, 400]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 380, 821, 400]]<|/det|>
Test, at the \(5\%\) significance level, whether the population mean time has decreased. [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Bottles of Lanta contain approximately \(300\mathrm{ml}\) of juice. The volume of juice, in millilitres, in a bottle is \(300 + X\), where \(X\) is a random variable with probability density function given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[327, 114, 667, 157]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}\frac{3}{4000} (100 - x^2) & -10\leqslant x\leqslant 10,\\ 0 & \mathrm{otherwise}. \end{array} \right.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 175, 146, 193]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 173, 915, 193]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that a randomly chosen bottle of Lanta contains more than \(305 \mathrm{ml}\) of juice.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 191, 917, 208]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 599, 186, 616]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 598, 838, 616]]<|/det|>
Given that \(25\%\) of bottles of Lanta contain more than \((300 + p) \mathrm{ml}\) of juice, show that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 622, 589, 643]]<|/det|>
\[p^{3} - 300p + 1000 = 0.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 623, 920, 642]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
The volumes, in millilitres, of large and small cups of tea are modelled by the distributions N(200, 30) and N(110, 20) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 146, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the total volume of a randomly chosen large cup of tea and a randomly chosen small cup of tea is less than 300 ml.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the volume of a randomly chosen large cup of tea is more than twice the volume of a randomly chosen small cup of tea.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
A national survey shows that \(95\%\) of year 12 students use social media. Arvin suspects that the percentage of year 12 students at his college who use social media is less than the national percentage. He chooses a random sample of 20 students at his college and notes the number who use social media. He then carries out a test at the \(2\%\) significance level.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 151, 146, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 151, 450, 170]]<|/det|>
Find the rejection region for the test.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 151, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 460, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the probability of a Type I error.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 74, 918, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 250, 146, 268]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 250, 920, 285]]<|/det|>
Jimmy believes that the true percentage at Arvin's college is \(70\%\). Assuming that Jimmy is correct, find the probability of a Type II error.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 266, 920, 285]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[482, 46, 510, 63]]<|/det|>
